Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase II: Monolithic Integration of LED Arrays and Silicon TFTs for Super High Brightness Microdisplays
Award.AbstractNarration:
This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase II project aims to develop a new high brightness light engine platform by monolithically integrating high performance silicon transistors with compound semiconductor optoelectronic materials. Dense arrays of light emitting diodes (LEDs) have been previously fabricated to show the opportunity of using such arrays in microdisplay and projection concepts. However, without active control circuits, the ultimate brightness and resolution are limited. The technology developed in this SBIR uniquely allows for the fabrication of LED arrays with integrated control circuits on a single substrate enabling a light engine platform with high peak brightness, high dynamic range, and high efficiency. Prototype LED arrays and transistor devices have been fabricated, and the next step to realize this platform is the development of advanced silicon circuitry to directly control the LED arrays and color generation methods to achieve full-color displays. The anticipated results of this project are on-chip driving circuits and development of color generation methods which will be integrated with arrays of LEDs to form a commercially-ready prototype.

The broader impact/commercial potential of this project is the development of a light engine with a power efficiency, brightness, cost, and form factor unavailable in incumbent systems. In particular, three markets are identified where this technology significant advantages over current technologies. These include the microdisplay market, the pico projector market, and the projector market. This light engine platform offers a small form factor, long lifetime, environmental robustness, high energy efficiency, and the high brightness required for sunlight readability. These features are necessary to create truly ubiquitous display devices and enable new see-through augmented reality experiences or smaller, more integrated portable projectors, not possible with current technologies. Commercialization of this device will impact all of these areas and also enable a range of new downstream applications including other non-display industries, such as, 3D scanning and novel user interfaces.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Lumiode is a New York City based semiconductor technology company building high-brightness micro-LED microdisplays. This SBIR project was used to develop Lumiode's core technology of integrating light emitting diode (LED) arrays with silicon thin-film transistors (TFT). By combining these two material systems, Lumiode successfully fabricated high-brightness and high-efficiency light emitters and active matrix control circuitry on the same substrate. Several areas of technology growth were supported by this SBIR. In particular, research efforts were focused on micro-LED performance, TFT performance and analysis, and development of a low temperature semiconductor process for LED-TFT integration. Through the course of this SBIR, there were a number of unforeseen issues where LED uniformity and performance were affected by specific portions of the transistor process. Lumiode worked throughout the SBIR project to develop each film and interface between the LED and TFT layers, ending with a scalable process that simultaneously maintained the performance of both the LED and TFT.  This research work was then expanded to optimize the semiconductor processes for transfer to production foundries. Through the use of SBIR funding and equity investment, Lumiode completed development of an integrated LED-TFT semiconductor process and formed relationships with early customers to continue customer-specific research. Lumiode also validated the need for high-brightness microdisplays in multiple market verticals, and is exploring first products in several adjacent areas.
